comments.commentBody: Sigh.  The notion that graduates in the Humanities, like polar artifacts, are somehow frozen does a disservice to us all.  The flexibility of thought and imagination acquired through great art and literature best suits us for the age, whatever the age may be.  Java is a great programming language, but will anyone be studying it two millennia the way we do Classical Greek?

Fact appears to be w/o the boss system where pols developed candidates who wanted to hold office (rather than hang out w/ Hollywood buddies), the primary system gives us superficial candidates supported by shallow press.
A sound bite is not a statement of policy, illiterate "in" instead of "ing", and folksy expressions like wrong headed make one aware that if there is a Lincoln out there he cannot get nominated today.

Doug,

You might want to read the history of the repeal of the Volstead Act! Bad legislation isn't sacred and the A.C.A. Is very bad legislation!

One great source of the President's unpopularity has been the relentless and very well funded effort to undermine and defeat him. This effort has been unprecedented in size, scope and planning in American history. The amount of money spent is staggering, in the hundreds of millions of dollars, some of which went to "encourage" the tea party in 2009.

The gridblocking of the US House of representatives has but one purpose: the nullification of the election results of 2008 and 2012. It is designed to make Obama look weak and ineffective so that the opposition can go around complaining that he is weak and ineffective.

The attack on "Obamacare", likewise, has been unrelenting. Never before to my knowledge have elected US Senators taken an active role in trying to defeat passed and signed legislation, as happened when some Republican senators, in but one of many such moves, tried to stop the NFL from helping to provide information about the health care law. This was gross interference in executive authority.

On top of all this, we have an intelligent, capable president who seems to lack the ability to project executive authority (at times), instead talking about limitations and incremental change rather than sounding like the commander-in-chief. When strength of will and action are needed, like now with the Israeli/Gaza war, Obama speaks of what we can't do. When military action is required, as with against ISIS, he orders bombing "if necessary".

http://terryreport.com

She speaks of "reclaiming" the White House... as if it were a military objective. That phrase makes me worry that if, heaven forbid, she actually gets elected she'll try to ignore future elections and never move out.

I am hoping against hope that there are other viable Democratic candidates besides Hillary Clinton. It's become increasingly apparent through the years that Ms. Clinton is cut from the same cloth as her duplicitious husband, which means she's an opportunist who will do and say whatever is necessary to get elected.

The Clintons are the embodiment of the stereotypical slimy politician, who measures every comment by whether its digestible to the broader electorate. Hillary Clinton wouldn't recognize her own thoughts, feelings, or opinions if they ran her over in a Mack truck.

When Hillary was pressed recently in an interview with Terry Gross about her continuously evolving position on gay marriage, she went on the attack. She did the same when she was asked about legalizing marijuana. Hillary is the kind of aloof and ethically challenged politician who identifies palatable (mushy middle) positions on issues and then works her political calculations back from there. As with her husband, her finger is always in the air determining which way the political winds are blowing. That impresses some voters but I'd rather have a principled candidate along the lines of an Elizabeth Warren or Bernie Sanders. You know, someone who actually knows who they are and has the courage to stand up for what they believe.

Woe betide anyone who dares to call out Hillary's hypocrisy. She expects Democrats to be asleep at the wheel but I want to believe that her miscalculations have caught up to her.

"having lived in the White House for eight years would give her the experience to navigate the office of president."

This is a qualification? How does Mrs. Clinton measure up against her own daughter Chelsea, Laura Bush, Nancy Reagan, and Barney the Dog? They all lived in the White House for eight years.
If that is a criteria for being President than most of the White House kitchen staff would be better qualified to be President than Hillary!

As an Independent voter, I'd vote for Hillary.  For better or worse, her connections, strength and having lived in the White House for eight years would give her the experience to navigate the office of president.  She certainly has more experience than our current president, even after his almost 6 years in the oval office.

comments.userLocation: Bronxville, NY, writing from Nosara, Costa Rica
comments.commentBody: Oops!  Too late.

It only makes political sense that Mrs. Clinton would distance herself from the President.  Anything that even remotely resembles a continuation of the Obama administration is going to be a death blow to any serious Democratic contender.  The Republicans will crawl all over that and the Democratic donors purse strings will close tighter than a nun's hand around a ruler.  Mrs. Clinton will not be doing any stupid stuff.

The United States does not need Hillary Clinton post Obama.  It needs fresh leadership which can deal with the challenges America faces today.  Another Clinton presidency shall only bring with it the status quo: A fatter and meaner Wall Street while the average American's living standard continues to decline, more unwise intervention abroad, millions more entering this country illegally, and an infrastructure approaching third world status.  Enough is enough.  Who can bring the United States back on track?  Not HRC!

I believe that there was a time in the past - the distant past - when Hillary Clinton had a genuine desire to serve society.  Now, it seems, she only cares to serve herself.  It's time for her to move over and allow the way for a real public-oriented leader like Elizabeth Warren.

I'm disappointed too.  I began to sense a shift in her when she was downright ugly on John Stewart's The Daily Show two weeks ago.  Yes, it was about her book, but she got political questions and mentioned policy.  There was not a single kind word of support for the President.  There was not a single word about voting for a sympathetic Congress in November.  I was shocked.  I mean, the President still has two and a half years to go, and we get the entire term of the 114th Congress before she ever lays claim to anything!
Nobody can top her government background and experience and she's ahead in the polls of all potential presidential candidates including Republicans.
Bear in mind that if half the Michigan and Florida delegates hadn't been disallowed (due to violating the primary schedule of the DNC) HRC would have bagged the nomination.
PLEASE  let his be true!!!

as much as I admire her, she just wants this too bad. That's exactly how she ended up on the outside in 2008.

We will have a female POTUS soon, but I think Elizabeth Warren will be the name on the desk.
I'm a woman who did not and who, now, will not support Hillary Clinton if she runs in 2016. She's NOT wise. I am a die-hard Obama mama if we're sticking in terms of gender.

I guess males have not noticed how the white male vote was cast for the white male in 2008 and 2012, while no woman ever could vote for a female; so males making up the fact that women are solely supporting Hillary because she is female, is just your gender bias showing...unattractive.  White males supported white male Romney by an overwhelming level.

"Hard Choices." Ha. How about "Cowardly Choices," such as her choice not to lead (when has she ever been a leader?) and lend her name to the opposition to the crazy idea in 2002 and 2003 of invading Iraq? I can never forgive her for her vote to authorize the Bush Administration to use force in Iraq.

It disappoints me to see women support Clinton in any part because of her gender. There's actually nothing wrong with a woman supporting a woman because of her gender, a Mexican-American supporting a Mexican-American candidate because of their heritage, etc., etc. But women could do a hell of a lot better than Hillary Clinton.

comments.userLocation: Bronxville, NY, writing from Nosara, Costa Rica
comments.commentBody: And yet she is behaving for all the world exactly as she would if she were a candidate:  on the campaign trail with Democratic candidates; national news releases pretty much every day; all over the social media, sometimes twice a day with new postings.  She may not be running now but she sure is positioning herself for the failure of number one which, by the way, seems to be hurtling down the road at us.  Looks like a repeat of of '08 -- Hillary, with the nomination in her pocket, crashes and burns.
Well said
Sadly Obama has never displayed the courage it would take to endorse Warren.  Maybe if it is his last hurrah ....
Hillary has done us all a favor. Now Obama is free to give his support to Elizabeth Warren.

Thanks for commenting, BB from Berkeley. I agree with you totally but unfortunately the 'war on drugs' does not extend to those prescribed by doctors. The entire tenor of society has been affected by the over prescription of all drugs. It has devastated us and no one seems to understand why.
I wonder if that policeman in Ferguson was on Adderral to help him cope with the stress. In almost every instance of some young person going berserk and acting out violently in school or society at large, they have been taking these drugs for years. It is never revealed what drugs or how long, only that they have been 'treated'. Wake up. America!
Of course, a psychologist does not/cannot prescribe so you would be skeptical of pharmaceuticals because if they work it puts you out of a job.

One man's poison is another man's remedy, lou Andrews. Don't be so quick to condemn all antidepressants because many of them do work; not all drugs work for all patients but it doesn't mean they do not work. That's misinformation.

For many years I worked emergency services as a psychologist.  We were able to lower the rate of suicide by providing service, educating gatekeepers (police, firefighters, physicians, nurses, clergy, etc.)  These days depression, as then, seems to be the root precipitating factor.  However it is my belief that the handfuls of psychotropic medications and particularly the anti-depresants may be the biggest cause.  I don't know if there is any research related to this notion but if one reads the side effects of most of these drugs suicide is one.  As time has turned, treatment for depression has evolved into the 'chemical imbalance' model and talk therapy has waned.  It is my belief that big pharma has greatly influenced this change thus shortchanging those that can be helped out of depression and perhaps with medication has driven folks deeper into depression and into suicide.  So when I hear of suicides I believe that the medical community and big pharma has short changed those people who are depressed.

"....... her calculation is that undermining Obama is good for her."

This essential point is the crux of the entire episode at hand.
It begs the question:
It is good for her ........ with whom - exactly.???

In my view she may not live down this very large blunder.
My advice to her is "Don't do stupid stuff."
She may have lost my vote as a result.
Hey, the Clintons are always there when they need you!  What more do you want?  Honesty?  Forget about it!!

I see no evidence that "he forgives her". In fact, I see evidence that disputes that. Hillary, alone, is spreading the "hug it out" meme as a form of humor + spin.

I don't think Obama or the administration thinks it's funny. Gail Collins is the only party in this package forgiving Hillary Clinton. This statement is amazing: "She was probably being neither politically calculating nor blundering in the Atlantic interview, but simply being unusually clear about what she believes."

She was just being "clear"?

Would she be "clear" about these beliefs if Obama was at 60% popularity? (No). Would she even possess these beliefs if Obama were popular?

Clinton's statements are the definition of "politically calculating" and her calculation is that undermining Obama is good for her. Period.

Great article.  The humanities will remain essential for the duration of humanity.  And yes Rawls offers an interesting way of thinking.  But one thing that Kristof failed to mention is that there is a segment of our populace who enjoy risk taking, and who would say behind the veil of ignorance that I want to take a chance that I have world class talent.  And I would want a society that maximized that talent.  Would that change people's views?

I agree we've had deplorable, but I don't put Obama in the group. He's up against cabals and do nothing congress. They hate him and do everything possible to discredit everything. No, he's not perfect and has made a few so-so picks for his cabinet, but given the fact they refloated the Titanic he got we owe him respect.

As for the carpetbagger, Ms Clinton, just say no. The terrible fact is that gerrymandering works and unless a pick brings out all possible voters who are smart enough to pick a patriot.. we're in suspension.
The Democratic Bosses have already fixed the primarries.  Push Bloomberg to run as an Independent.

Hillary Rodham owes her very continued political existence to her current island-mate—"Don't do dumb stuff." [Perhaps that cabinet appointment WAS part of the "dumb stuff".]

We SO need new blood and new thinking.

And we've had SUCH a string of deplorably BAD to MEDIOCRE presidents!

PLEASE no more Hillary Rodham.

There must be numbers of women (and men, although 2016 appears to have been ordained a poster-child election for a woman president) in the mold of Elizabeth Warren that we need to hear from.

PLEASE come forward: your country needs you.

The impartial choice, form the "original position" (i.e. not knowing how one will be born, or what circumstances he might face) does "institutionalize empathy" in the sense that policy is determined with consideration of the worst case scenario and people who face it. The decision is made out of self-interest, but its result is empathetic because the scenario may or may not affect the decision maker, but consideration is given to the person who must face it, whether that be the decision maker or not. It is not a perfectly empathetic scenario, but a form of empathy resulting from the "original position." If I don't know where I'll be, I must consider the possibility that I'll be in a bad situation, so I set policy to protect those in that bad situation. It is a decision made based on impartiality, but also a form of empathy.

Rawls does assert a principle of justice which says that the interest of the worst off member of society is to maximized, but he does not get to that point a premise that there is or should be empathy.  He gets there from what he considers to be impartial choice.  Empathy is taking the other person's interest into account.  Rawls insists that this not be done.  Where would empathy take us?  I think to a different point.  Rawls only thinks that the interest of the worst off would be guarded, by the difference principle as it were.  But empathy would lead to a more generous principle.  Stemming from the premise that each person should or does in some way take everyone else's interest into account would deal with economic inequalities in a more pervasive way, not just the interest of the worst off, important though that no doubt is

Rawls does not call for institutionalizing empathy at all.  Quite to the contrary, his objective is to define circumstances of justice, that is, conditions of impartial, unbiased choice, in which a self-interested person will chose principles of justice that will maximize his own good.  Rawls is explicit, the principles of justice  are based on a conception of a person who does not take an interest in anyone else's interest, because he does not consider the alternative to be a realistic idea.  It is important not just to tout the humanities but to understand them as well. Rawls theory is more a reflection of our society of self-interested persons than it is a lesson in another conception of the person and society.   Perhaps Mr. Kristoff can go back to the books to find a scholarly explar of the idea he is seeking.

Excellent, Marco M! You have the same insight as Tim Lewis #19 for spotting the alternating role of the cats. You are in effect taking the difference of the positions in his formulation. I am wondering how you could use this representation to deduce the exact conditions on $\alpha$ and $\beta$ for vanishing and nonvanishing of the distance between the cats-quirrelfrog distance in the generalized version.

John,

A heady choice of avatar.

"having lived in the White House for eight years would give her the experience to navigate the office of president."

This is a qualification? How does Mrs. Clinton measure up against her own daughter Chelsea, Laura Bush, Nancy Reagan, and Barney the Dog? They all lived in the White House for eight years.
Saint-Saëns' first name was, of course, Camille. (Lazy finger, I guess.)

I never heard Robin Williams interviewed about his mental state but I wouldn't be surprised if he had denied being bipolar (if asked).  He might very well have been in denial or doubt about it.  Many people with this condition and related often are and as a result refuse to take medication.  My brother was one of them (he killed himself in August of 2008).  It's one of the many reasons mental illness of this depth and degree is so hard to treat.

It is quite possible to both, dairubo. My alma mater, Columbia, has done so for decades. The first two years offer a mind-opening preparation in the liberal arts, via what is known as the Core Course. In junior and senior years one is allowed to concentrate on majors, which in my case was a solid grounding in business admin. and economics. The combination has served me very well in life. It not only helped me to become self-supporting after graduation, but whetted a love of learning that continues into my financially comfortable old age. I highly recommend it.
Yours is a pipe dream. (though it is what we need) When our president makes fun of art history majors, you can be assured that no change will be coming. we are awash in meaningless jibberish, alas.

How nice of Nick Kristof to speak out in favor of education. So rare these days! Universities now serve the purpose of sorting people into those who will do as they are told and those who won't. Give up on yourself and study business (a process invented and evolved over time and then developed into the corporate model by people like Rockefeller Carnegie who did not go to college) and you will be a safe hire. Programing a computer does not require education.

But despite having some insight, NK buys into the devaluation of education and the overvaluing of such things as smartphones and tablet as enrichments to our world. Time will tell whether these things are neutral or, more likely, a distraction and detriment. Schools interested in education ban students from using them.

To improve the economy we need to close the business schools, and put educated people back in charge, people with liberal educations in history, languages, literature, philosophy, mathematics, music, art. A profound knowledge of medieval history from a rigorous liberal arts BA is a better employment qualification than a prestigious MBA in Finance, and that includes for jobs in the financial sector.

And that is just a minor point. Most importantly we will be better individually and as a society if we get back to real education.

So, Nick, good for you. Try not to despair. Maybe the universities can still be saved. And even if not, self education can work, and without student debt slavery.

I am one of the registered democrats who did not hopefully vote for Obama's hope hype. Instead, I wrote in Hillary Clinton's name in the voting booth and after these six long years, I am still satisfied that I did. That Obama put forth an idea to reduce Social Security more than offsets his ACA (which in my opinion should have been single payer rather than the complicated insurance industry program it is).
All of these recent op-eds in the NYT, especially the ones written by Maureen Dowd bring out such an onslaught of negative comments about Ms. Clinton. To me, it seems a bit of a replay of .the media's negativity towards her in 2008 as they swooned for Obama. She's a smart and skillful politician and we could do much worse than having her as our elected president in 2016. All of the negative commentary makes me wonder if the NYT and the commenters really would prefer that a really right wing Republican be elected as the next POTUS. Keep tearing Hillary Clinton down and you may get a Supreme Court you abhor for years to come.

You know Richard Nixon had tons of experience in government, but what really matters in the end is how good a person you really are. Frankly neither Clinton or Obama impress me as caring, real people. The Democrats--the country--need to go to the left toward peace, toward compassion and understanding for other people, not to the right, where Clinton is, toward more conflicts and more greed in peoples' lives.

I have serious doubts that the Democratic Party can rise to the occassion.

This Hillary-Obama kerfuffle will be long forgotten as she's every right to express her independence. Moreover, no one can top her in government background and experience; and she's leading in the polls of all presidential hopefuls including Republicans. If she runs, she wins. And with Obama's endorsement too!
